chapters.title: Phishing Campaign Delivering Three Fileless Malware: AveMariaRAT / BitRAT / PandoraHVNC Part II

sentences.text: Fortinets FortiGuard Labs captured a phishing campaign that delivers three fileless malware onto a victims device. Once executed, they are able to control and steal sensitive information from that device to perform other actions according to the control commands from their server.
sentences.html: Fortinet’s FortiGuard Labs captured a phishing campaign that delivers three fileless malware onto a victim’s device. Once executed, they are able to control and steal sensitive information from that device to perform other actions according to the control commands from their server.

sentences.text: In Part I of this analysis, I introduced how these three fileless malware are delivered to the victims device via a phishing campaign, and what mechanism it uses to load, deploy, and execute these fileless malware in the target process.
sentences.html: In Part I of this analysis, I introduced how these three fileless malware are delivered to the victim’s device via a phishing campaign, and what mechanism it uses to load, deploy, and execute these fileless malware in the target process.

sentences.text: In Part II, I will focus on the three malware payloads and elaborate on how they steal sensitive information from the victims device, how they submit data to their C2 server, details about the control commands, as well as what they can perform with those control commands.
sentences.html: In Part II, I will focus on the three malware payloads and elaborate on how they steal sensitive information from the victim’s device, how they submit data to their C2 server, details about the control commands, as well as what they can perform with those control commands.

sentences.text: Affected platforms: Microsoft Windows<crlf>Impacted parties: Microsoft Windows Users<crlf>Impact: Controls victims device and collects sensitive information<crlf>Severity level: Critical
sentences.html: Affected platforms: Microsoft Windows Impacted parties: Microsoft Windows Users Impact: Controls victim’s device and collects sensitive information Severity level: Critical

sentences.text: Ave Maria is a RAT (Remote Access Trojan), also known as WARZONE RAT. It offers a wide range of features, such as stealing victims sensitive information and remote controlling an infected device, including privilege escalation, remote desktop control, camera capturing, and more.
sentences.html: “Ave Maria” is a RAT (Remote Access Trojan), also known as WARZONE RAT. It offers a wide range of features, such as stealing victim’s sensitive information and remote controlling an infected device, including privilege escalation, remote desktop control, camera capturing, and more.

sentences.text: It is the first of the three malware (refer to Figure 3.3 of the previous analysis) to be injected into a newly-created aspnet_compiler.exe process on the victims device and then run.
sentences.html: It is the first of the three malware (refer to Figure 3.3 of the previous analysis) to be injected into a newly-created “aspnet_compiler.exe” process on the victim’s device and then run.

sentences.text: Ave Maria has a configuration block that is RC4 encrypted within its PE structures .bss section. The decryption key and encrypted data are together within the .bss. When the malware starts, it first decrypts the configuration block. Figure 1.1 shows the decrypted data in memory.
sentences.html: Ave Maria has a configuration block that is RC4 encrypted within its PE structure’s “.bss” section. The decryption key and encrypted data are together within the “.bss”. When the malware starts, it first decrypts the configuration block. Figure 1.1 shows the decrypted data in memory.

sentences.text: Figure 1.1 RC4-decrypted configuration block
sentences.html: Figure 1.1 – RC4-decrypted configuration block

sentences.text: It not only contains the C2 server (mubbibun.duckdns.org) and port (0x3E7), but also a number of switch flags, such as whether to add itself into the auto-run group, bypass UAC (User Account Control), or bypass Windows Defender.
sentences.html: It not only contains the C2 server (“mubbibun.duckdns.org”) and port (0x3E7), but also a number of switch flags, such as whether to add itself into the auto-run group, bypass UAC (User Account Control), or bypass Windows Defender.

sentences.text: Once Ave Maria establishes its connection to the C2 server it starts to control the victims device. According to my research, the traffic between its client and the C2 server is RC4 encrypted with a constant encryption key "warzone160".
sentences.html: Once Ave Maria establishes its connection to the C2 server it starts to control the victim’s device. According to my research, the traffic between its client and the C2 server is RC4 encrypted with a constant encryption key "warzone160".

sentences.text: Ill explain what the plaintext packet consists of through an instance packet as below.
sentences.html: I’ll explain what the plaintext packet consists of through an instance packet as below.

sentences.text: The first dword 0xE466BB29 is a magic value; each packet must start with this value.<crlf>The 0xEA70 is the size of the command data. It is 0x0 if no command data.<crlf>The 0x1E is the command number of this packet.<crlf>The subsequence data is the command data, which is an executable file in this example packet. It doesnt appear if there is no command data for the command.
sentences.html:
• The first dword 0xE466BB29 is a magic value; each packet must start with this value.
  • The 0xEA70 is the size of the command data. It is 0x0 if no command data.
  • The 0x1E is the command number of this packet.
  • The subsequence data is the command data, which is an executable file in this example packet. It doesn’t appear if there is no command data for the command.

sentences.text: Ave Maria provides these features:
sentences.html: Ave Maria provides these features:

sentences.text: Remote VNC (Virtual Network Computing), Remote Shell, File Explorer, Process Manager, Remote Webcam, Password Manager, Reverse Socks, Download & Execute a file, Remote Keylogger, HRDP Manager as well as Privilege Escalation.
sentences.html: Remote VNC (Virtual Network Computing), Remote Shell, File Explorer, Process Manager, Remote Webcam, Password Manager, Reverse Socks, Download & Execute a file, Remote Keylogger, HRDP Manager as well as Privilege Escalation.

sentences.text: Figure 1.2 Display of Remote Keylogger feature
sentences.html: Figure 1.2 – Display of Remote Keylogger feature

sentences.text: Figure 1.2 shows the feature (on the C2 server side) of the online Remote Keylogger (command 24H). You can see here what is recorded when I open a Chrome browser and type in www.fortinet.com and press Enter on a victims device.
sentences.html: Figure 1.2 shows the feature (on the C2 server side) of the online Remote Keylogger (command 24H). You can see here what is recorded when I open a Chrome browser and type in “www.fortinet.com” and press Enter on a victim’s device.

sentences.text: Its Password Manager feature aims to steal credentials from a group of apps, listed below, including internet browsers and email clients.
sentences.html: Its Password Manager feature aims to steal credentials from a group of apps, listed below, including internet browsers and email clients.

sentences.text: Google Chrome, Epic Privacy browser, Microsoft Edge, UCBrowser, Tencent QQBrowser, Opera, Blisk, Chromium, Brave-Browser, Vivaldi, Comodo Dragon, Torch, Slim, CentBrowser, Microsoft Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Outlook, Microsoft Messaging, Mozilla Thunderbird, Tencent Foxmail, and more.
sentences.html: Google Chrome, Epic Privacy browser, Microsoft Edge, UCBrowser, Tencent QQBrowser, Opera, Blisk, Chromium, Brave-Browser, Vivaldi, Comodo Dragon, Torch, Slim, CentBrowser, Microsoft Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Outlook, Microsoft Messaging, Mozilla Thunderbird, Tencent Foxmail, and more.

sentences.text: Figure 1.3 The pseudo code of stealing credentials
sentences.html: Figure 1.3 – The pseudo code of stealing credentials

sentences.text: Figure 1.3 is a screenshot of the pseudo code where Ave Maria steals the credentials (command 20H) from the defined files for several internet browsers. It calls a function to RC4-encrypt the credentials and send them to the C2 server.
sentences.html: Figure 1.3 is a screenshot of the pseudo code where Ave Maria steals the credentials (command 20H) from the defined files for several internet browsers. It calls a function to RC4-encrypt the credentials and send them to the C2 server.

sentences.text: Table 1.1 presents most of the control commands that Ave Maria supports.
sentences.html: Table 1.1 presents most of the control commands that Ave Maria supports.

1.1: Ask for basic information of the victim’s device.
1.5: Retrieve a file from Ave Maria home folder (%LocalAppData%\Microsoft Vision\) on the victim device.
1.12: Obtain the title of the active program.
1.13: Uninstall Ave Maria client from the victim’s device.
1.14: Transfer a file from C2 server to the victim's device.
1.15: Transfer an executable file to the victim’s device and run.
1.16: Obtain the credentials of the apps from the victim’s device.
1.17: Download a file from a given URL and execute.
1.20: Install HRDP Manager on the victim's device.
1.21: Reverse connect to C2 server for HRDP.
1.25: Execute a specified file on the victim's device.
1.28: Transfer a file to the victim.
1.29: Retrieve a folder from the victim device.

sentences.html:
Cmd Num

Description

00H

Ask for basic information of the victim’s device.

02H

List running processes.

04H

Start File Explorer.

06H

Navigate file.

08H

Retrieve a file from Ave Maria home folder (%LocalAppData%\Microsoft Vision\) on the victim device.

0AH

Delete a file.

0Ch

Kill a process.

0EH

Execute a shell command.

12H

List victim’s camera device information.

14H

Start victim’s camera.

16H

Stop the camera.

18H

Obtain the title of the active program.

1Ah

Uninstall Ave Maria client from the victim’s device.

1Ch

Transfer a file from C2 server to the victim's device.

1EH

Transfer an executable file to the victim’s device and run.

20H

Obtain the credentials of the apps from the victim’s device.

22H

Download a file from a given URL and execute.

24H

Start the online keylogger.

26H

Stop the online keylogger.

28H

Install HRDP Manager on the victim's device.

2AH

Reverse connect to C2 server for HRDP.

30H

Start the Remote VNC.

32H

Stop the Remote VNC

38H

Start reverse sock.

3AH

Execute a specified file on the victim's device.

3CH

Start the offline keylogger.

3EH,40H

Privilege Escalation.

48H

Transfer a file to the victim.

4AH

Retrieve a folder from the victim device.

sentences.text: Table 1.1 Ave Marias Control Commands
sentences.html: Table 1.1 – Ave Maria’s Control Commands

sentences.text: It collects basic information from the victims device and sends it to the C2 server to register the client in the server. Below is the data of such packet.
sentences.html: It collects basic information from the victim’s device and sends it to the C2 server to register the client in the server. Below is the data of such packet.

sentences.text: Figure 2.2 The registration packet to the C2 server
sentences.html: Figure 2.2 – The registration packet to the C2 server

sentences.text: The first 64-bit integer 0x62 is the entire packet size. The subsequent data is sealed in a serialized binary object. The 16H data (00 01 0000) is kind of header. The next 0x4a is the size of the following strings, which is a variable length integer. The last 0x0b is a close flag.
sentences.html: The first 64-bit integer 0x62 is the entire packet size. The subsequent data is sealed in a serialized binary object. The 16H data (“00 01 … 0000”) is kind of header. The next 0x4a is the size of the following strings, which is a variable length integer. The last 0x0b is a close flag.

sentences.text: Lets take a look the sealed string, which consists of a packet number (654321), client group id (3H4RHL), the victims username and pc name (Bobs@BOBS-PC), the victims location code (US), the system information (Windows 7 Pro), date (05/09/2022), client version (3.1), and whether any antivirus product is being used (False).
sentences.html: Let’s take a look the sealed string, which consists of a packet number (“654321”), client group id (“3H4RHL”), the victim’s username and pc name (“Bobs@BOBS-PC”), the victim’s location code (“US”), the system information (“Windows 7 Pro”), date (“05/09/2022”), client version (“3.1”), and whether any antivirus product is being used (“False”).

sentences.text: Once the C2 server receives this packet, it shows the victims information in a list, as shown in Figure 2.3, Connected client.
sentences.html: Once the C2 server receives this packet, it shows the victim’s information in a list, as shown in Figure 2.3, “Connected client”.

sentences.text: Figure 2.3 - PandoraHVNC RAT C2 server interface and features
sentences.html: Figure 2.3 - PandoraHVNC RAT C2 server interface and features

sentences.text: The hacker is then able to control the victims machine by right-clicking the client and clicking the items on the menu. Figure 2.3 also demonstrates the right-click menu and features.
sentences.html: The hacker is then able to control the victim’s machine by right-clicking the client and clicking the items on the menu. Figure 2.3 also demonstrates the right-click menu and features.

sentences.text: Figure 2.4 The credentials packet to C2 server
sentences.html: Figure 2.4 – The credentials packet to C2 server

sentences.text: Figure 2.4 is a screenshot of two packets, the first line is the received command control packet with command number 3308. The rest is the packet sent to the C2 server with packet number 3308. This is followed by the stolen credentials from the victim when Pandora Recovery is clicked by the hacker. As mentioned before, the two packets are sealed in the serialized binary object.
sentences.html: Figure 2.4 is a screenshot of two packets, the first line is the received command control packet with command number “3308”. The rest is the packet sent to the C2 server with packet number “3308”. This is followed by the stolen credentials from the victim when “Pandora Recovery” is clicked by the hacker. As mentioned before, the two packets are sealed in the serialized binary object.

sentences.text: Table 2.1 demonstrates the details of all the control commands and features that PandoraHVNC RAT provides.
sentences.html: Table 2.1 demonstrates the details of all the control commands and features that PandoraHVNC RAT provides.

1.9: Move the mouse to a given point.
1.10: Send the data of the system clipboard to its C2 server.
1.11: Set given data to system clipboard.
1.12: Start a Chrome browser with specified parameters.
1.13: Start Mozilla Firefox with specified parameters.
1.16: Show Pandora HVNC Rat to the victim.
1.17: Show a pop-up message to the victim.
1.23: Start Microsoft Edge browser with specified parameters
1.24: Start Brave browser with specified parameters
1.25: Call KillMiner() to kill a process.
1.26: Download a file into %temp% folder as a Miner.
1.28: Start an Opera browser with specified parameters.
1.34: Push data to override the system clipboard.
1.35: Obtain the data from the system clipboard.
1.36: Obtain credentials and cookies from the victim’s browsers.
1.39: Start a Chrome browser with a default URL.
1.42: Same as 56. Download a file and execute.

sentences.html:
Cmd Num

Description

0

Start to capture the screenshot.

1

Abort the screenshot.

2

Simulate mouse left button DOWN.

3

Simulate mouse right button DOWN.

4

Simulate mouse left button UP.

5

Simulate mouse right button UP.

6

Perform mouse double click.

7

Simulate to press a Key.

8

Move the mouse to a given point.

9

Send the data of the system clipboard to its C2 server.

10

Set given data to system clipboard.

11

Start a Chrome browser with specified parameters.

12

Start Mozilla Firefox with specified parameters.

13

Show the StartMenu.

14

Minimize Pandora HVNC Rat.

15

Show Pandora HVNC Rat to the victim.

16

Show a pop-up message to the victim.

17

Set screenshot interval.

18

Set screenshot quality.

19

Set screenshot size.

21

Start Explorer program.

24

30

Start Microsoft Edge browser with specified parameters

32

Start Brave browser with specified parameters

50

Call KillMiner() to kill a process.

55

Download a file into %temp% folder as a Miner.

56

Download a file and execute.

444

Start an Opera browser with specified parameters.

555

Restart Outlook.

556

Restart FoxMail.

557

Restart Thunderbird.

666

Kill current Pandora HVNC Rat.

1337

Send Pong packet.

3306

Push data to override the system clipboard.

3307

Obtain the data from the system clipboard.

3308

Obtain credentials and cookies from the victim’s browsers.

4875

Start a CMD program.

4876

Start a PowerShell program.

8585

Start a Chrome browser with a default URL.

8586

Kill all Chrome browsers.

8587

Reset Scale.

8589

Same as 56. Download a file and execute.

sentences.text: Table 2.1 - List of control commands of PandoraHVNC RAT
sentences.html: Table 2.1 - List of control commands of PandoraHVNC RAT

sentences.text: BitRat is more powerful than AveMariaRAT and PandoraHVNC because it provides a great number of control commands (172 commands) to control the victims device.
sentences.html: BitRat is more powerful than AveMariaRAT and PandoraHVNC because it provides a great number of control commands (172 commands) to control the victim’s device.

sentences.text: Figure 3.4 shows the dashboard to a connected victim on the C2 server side. On the left is the basic information of the victims device, while there are some features listed on the right.
sentences.html: Figure 3.4 shows the dashboard to a connected victim on the C2 server side. On the left is the basic information of the victim’s device, while there are some features listed on the right.

sentences.text: Figure 3.4 Dashboard and features that BitRat supports
sentences.html: Figure 3.4 – Dashboard and features that BitRat supports

sentences.text: Other than the features from the dashboard, it also supports the following features from the main context menu:
sentences.html: Other than the features from the dashboard, it also supports the following features from the main context menu:

sentences.text: Chat<crlf>Clear browsers<crlf>Clipboard management<crlf>DLL injection<crlf>Change desktop background<crlf>Open website<crlf>Notes<crlf>UAC bypass<crlf>Kill Windows Defender<crlf>Show preview of screen or webcam<crlf>Keylog download & search<crlf>Reverse socks<crlf>System management (reboot, shutdown, sleep, etc.)<crlf>BitRat clients update and uninstall<crlf>DDoS attack (plugin)<crlf>Mining (plugin)<crlf>Telegram bot (plugin)<crlf>Passwords Logins (plugin)<crlf>And more

sentences.text: The second fileless malware injected into RegAsm.exe is PandorahVNC Rat, which is a commercial software. It was developed using C#, a Microsoft .Net framework. It supports features to steal credentials from some popular applications, like Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Firefox, Outlook, Foxmail, and so on. It also supports control commands to control the victims device, such as starting a process, capturing the screenshot, manipulating the victims mouse and keyboard, and more.
sentences.html: The second fileless malware injected into “RegAsm.exe” is “PandorahVNC Rat,” which is a commercial software. It was developed using C#, a Microsoft .Net framework. It supports features to steal credentials from some popular applications, like Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Firefox, Outlook, Foxmail, and so on. It also supports control commands to control the victim’s device, such as starting a process, capturing the screenshot, manipulating the victim’s mouse and keyboard, and more.

sentences.text: When it starts, it defines the following variables. They are the C2 server address, port, and the group id that will be used when sending data to the C2 server.
sentences.html: When it starts, it defines the following variables. They are the C2 server address, port, and the group id that will be used when sending data to the C2 server.

sentences.text: string str = "vncgoga.duckdns.org"; //C2 server<crlf>string str2 = "1338"; // TCP port<crlf>string identifier = "3H4RHL"; // Group id
sentences.html: string str = "vncgoga.duckdns.org"; //C2 server string str2 = "1338"; // TCP port string identifier = "3H4RHL"; // Group id

sentences.text: Next, it proceeds to extract a core module from a base64-encoded string, which performs all features of PandoraHVNC RAT. It then deploys the core module into a newly-created process, cvtres.exe (a file from Microsoft .Net framework), using process hollowing. It tries to find the file from one of the following:
sentences.html: Next, it proceeds to extract a core module from a base64-encoded string, which performs all features of PandoraHVNC RAT. It then deploys the core module into a newly-created process, “cvtres.exe” (a file from Microsoft .Net framework), using process hollowing. It tries to find the file from one of the following:

sentences.text: C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\"<crlf>"C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v2.0.50727\
sentences.html: “C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\" "C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v2.0.50727\”

sentences.text: If it fails to locate the file, it quits without running PandoraHVNC RATs core module. The C2 server address, port, and group id will be passed to the new process during the process hollowing. Figure 2.1 shows the code segment to perform the process hollowing.
sentences.html: If it fails to locate the file, it quits without running PandoraHVNC RAT’s core module. The C2 server address, port, and group id will be passed to the new process during the process hollowing. Figure 2.1 shows the code segment to perform the process hollowing.

sentences.text: Figure 2.1 Code to perform the process hollowing
sentences.html: Figure 2.1 – Code to perform the process hollowing

sentences.text: BitRat has a configuration block encrypted similar to the Ave Maria Rat. Figure 3.1 shows the just decrypted configuration block in memory, where it contains C2 server (maraipasoo[.]duckdns[.]org) & port (890), client ID (f2b8b66873ca913a), and more.
sentences.html: BitRat has a configuration block encrypted similar to the Ave Maria Rat. Figure 3.1 shows the just decrypted configuration block in memory, where it contains C2 server (“maraipasoo[.]duckdns[.]org”) & port (890), client ID (“f2b8b66873ca913a”), and more.

sentences.text: Figure 3.1 Decrypted configuration block
sentences.html: Figure 3.1 – Decrypted configuration block

sentences.text: It proceeds to connect to the C2 server. It then uses TLS 1.2 protocol plus a cipher suite of RAS+AES 256 to transfer and encrypt its packet. Figure 3.2 shows the model that it uses to encode the plain text data with Base64 and encrypt with AES-256. And finally, it sends the encrypted data to the C2 server over TLS 1.2 protocol.
sentences.html: It proceeds to connect to the C2 server. It then uses TLS 1.2 protocol plus a cipher suite of RAS+AES 256 to transfer and encrypt its packet. Figure 3.2 shows the model that it uses to encode the plain text data with Base64 and encrypt with AES-256. And finally, it sends the encrypted data to the C2 server over TLS 1.2 protocol.

sentences.text: Figure 3.2 The outline of how a packet is transformed and sent to the C2 server
sentences.html: Figure 3.2 – The outline of how a packet is transformed and sent to the C2 server

sentences.text: Ill take a moment here to explain what the plaintext packet looks like. Figure 3.3, below, is a screenshot of the debugger when BitRat was about to Base64-encode the plaintext packet with the basic information of the victims device.
sentences.html: I’ll take a moment here to explain what the plaintext packet looks like. Figure 3.3, below, is a screenshot of the debugger when BitRat was about to Base64-encode the plaintext packet with the basic information of the victim’s device.

sentences.text: Figure 3.3 Basic information packet before Base64 encoding
sentences.html: Figure 3.3 – Basic information packet before Base64 encoding

sentences.text: The packet consists of many parts separated by |, including a client ID (f2b8b66873ca913a), user name, computer name, CPU information, GPU card, system name (Win 7), systems uptime, system idle time, RAM amount, IP address, whether or not the login user is an administrator, BitRat client version (1.38), and so on. Next, the packet goes through Base64-encoding and AES-256 encryption, which is eventually sent to the C2 server.
sentences.html: The packet consists of many parts separated by “|”, including a client ID (“f2b8b66873ca913a”), user name, computer name, CPU information, GPU card, system name (“Win 7”), system’s uptime, system idle time, RAM amount, IP address, whether or not the login user is an administrator, BitRat client version (“1.38”), and so on. Next, the packet goes through Base64-encoding and AES-256 encryption, which is eventually sent to the C2 server.

sentences.text: Once the C2 server receives this packet, the victims device shows up in its control interface, where the hacker is able to control the infected device.
sentences.html: Once the C2 server receives this packet, the victim’s device shows up in its control interface, where the hacker is able to control the infected device.

sentences.text: The third fileless malware injected into aspnet_compiler.exe is BitRat, which is said to be a high quality and efficient RAT. It provides information collection like clipboard logger, keylogger, application credentials, Webcam logging, and Voice Recording. It has wide control commands for controlling the victims device, including downloading and executing a file, performing remote desktop control, controlling processes and services, reverse socks, and more.
sentences.html: The third fileless malware injected into “aspnet_compiler.exe” is “BitRat”, which is said to be a high quality and efficient RAT. It provides information collection like clipboard logger, keylogger, application credentials, Webcam logging, and Voice Recording. It has wide control commands for controlling the victim’s device, including downloading and executing a file, performing remote desktop control, controlling processes and services, reverse socks, and more.

sentences.text: While BitRat receives the control command packet, it only needs a AES-256 decryption to restore the plaintext packet. I will explain the structure of a plaintext command packet using the following example:
sentences.html: While BitRat receives the control command packet, it only needs a AES-256 decryption to restore the plaintext packet. I will explain the structure of a plaintext command packet using the following example:

sentences.text: "ddos_start|MTkyLjE2OC4yMi4xNQ==|3333|1|tcp|tcp|1|0|L3NpdGUucGhwP3g9dmFsMSZ5PXZhbDI="
sentences.html: "ddos_start|MTkyLjE2OC4yMi4xNQ==|3333|1|tcp|tcp|1|0|L3NpdGUucGhwP3g9dmFsMSZ5PXZhbDI="

sentences.text: Every command packet starts with a command name string and subsequent parameters, which are separated by |.
sentences.html: Every command packet starts with a command name string and subsequent parameters, which are separated by “|”.

sentences.text: The above example command asks the infected device to start a DDoS attack, where ddos_start is the command name, MTkyLjE2OC4yMi4xNQ== is the Base64-encoded target IP, 3333 is the target port, flood method is tcp, protocol is tcp, thread number is 1, size is 0, and the last field is the data.
sentences.html: The above example command asks the infected device to start a DDoS attack, where “ddos_start” is the command name, “MTkyLjE2OC4yMi4xNQ==” is the Base64-encoded target IP, “3333” is the target port, flood method is “tcp”, protocol is “tcp”, thread number is “1”, size is “0”, and the last field is the data.

sentences.text: On the very first time, BitRat initializes a linked list with nodes containing a command name and a command number (like ddos_start for 85H) as well as some flags. BitRat has a method to go through these nodes looking for a node that matches the command name from the packet by string comparison. The command name starts at offset +10H of the node and the corresponding command number is saved in a dword at offset +28H. Below is a dumped node of ddos_start.
sentences.html: On the very first time, BitRat initializes a linked list with nodes containing a command name and a command number (like “ddos_start” for 85H) as well as some flags. BitRat has a method to go through these nodes looking for a node that matches the command name from the packet by string comparison. The command name starts at offset +10H of the node and the corresponding command number is saved in a dword at offset +28H. Below is a dumped node of “ddos_start”.

sentences.text: BitRat performs the action according to the command number. Table 3.1 lists the most control commands, with brief command descriptions that BitRat supports.
sentences.html: BitRat performs the action according to the command number. Table 3.1 lists the most control commands, with brief command descriptions that BitRat supports.

Cmd Name

Num

Description

"cli_up"

00H

Update BitRat client.

"rc"

01H

Reconnect to the C2 server.

"cli_dc"

02H

Disconnect to the C2 server.

"cli_un"

03H

Uninstall BitRat client from the victim's device.

"cli_sleep"

04H

Put the victim's system into sleep.

"cli_hib"

05H

Put the victim's system into hibernation.

"cli_log"

06H

Have the victim's system to log out the current user.

"cli_rs"

07H

Restart the victim's device.

"cli_off"

08H

Shutdown the victim's device.

"cli_bsod"

09H

Make the victim's system crash with a blue screen.

"info"

0AH

Request for the basic information of the victim's device.

0BH

0CH

1AH

85H

87H

89H

93H

94H

"s_list"

95H

List the tasks from the system Task Scheduler of the infected system.

96H

"spread"

97H

98H

Change the desktop background of the victim's desktop.

99H

9BH

Close the browsers such as Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Opera, IE, Vivaldi, Brave, Chromium, Torch, UCBrowser and clean its data.

9CH

Obtain notes that were set to the victim’s device.

"notes_set"

9DH

Set notes to the victim device.

"website_open"

9FH

Open a website with the default web browser on the victim's device.

"vol_edit"

A0H

"msgbox"

A3H

Display the victim a message box with a message.

"clipboard_get"

A2H

Obtain the system clipboard data from the victim's system.

"injdll"

A4H

Inject a dll into a specified process or all processes.

"chat_start"

A9H

Pop up a chatting box to the victim.

"chat_msg"

AAH

Chat with the victim using the chatting box.

"chat_stop"

ABH

Stop chatting.

sentences.html: Table 3.1 – The most control commands of BitRat

sentences.text: In this second part the series, I examined the three fileless malware payloads included in the phishing campaign. I also explained what processes they inject into and execute.
sentences.html: In this second part the series, I examined the three fileless malware payloads included in the phishing campaign. I also explained what processes they inject into and execute.

sentences.text: Next, I introduced how these three malware connect to their C2 server and described the structure of the packets sending to the C2 server. I also presented the values in the control command packets sent to the malware clients to control the victims device to perform further malicious tasks.
sentences.html: Next, I introduced how these three malware connect to their C2 server and described the structure of the packets sending to the C2 server. I also presented the values in the control command packets sent to the malware clients to control the victim’s device to perform further malicious tasks.

sentences.text: I elaborated the features that the three malware provide and used several examples to prove how the attacker uses them. From my research, you also learned the differences between their features.
sentences.html: I elaborated the features that the three malware provide and used several examples to prove how the attacker uses them. From my research, you also learned the differences between their features.

sentences.text: I also made three tables to list the control commands with brief descriptions.
sentences.html: I also made three tables to list the control commands with brief descriptions.

sentences.text: Fortinet customers are already protected from this malware by FortiGuards Web Filtering, AntiVirus, FortiMail, FortiClient, FortiEDR services and CDR (content disarm and reconstruction) feature, as follows:
sentences.html: Fortinet customers are already protected from this malware by FortiGuard’s Web Filtering, AntiVirus, FortiMail, FortiClient, FortiEDR services and CDR (content disarm and reconstruction) feature, as follows:

sentences.text: All relevant URLs have been rated as "Malicious Websites" by the FortiGuard Web Filtering service.
sentences.html: All relevant URLs have been rated as "Malicious Websites" by the FortiGuard Web Filtering service.

sentences.text: The phishing email attached Excel document can be disarmed by the FortiGuard CDR (content disarm and reconstruction) feature.
sentences.html: The phishing email attached Excel document can be disarmed by the FortiGuard CDR (content disarm and reconstruction) feature.

sentences.text: The captured Excel sample at the beginning and the downloaded html file as well as the Powershell file with three fileless malware payload files are detected as "VBA/Agent.DDON!tr", "JS/Agent.DDON!tr.dldr" and "PowerShell/Agent.e535!tr" and are blocked by the FortiGuard Antivirus service.
sentences.html: The captured Excel sample at the beginning and the downloaded html file as well as the Powershell file with three fileless malware payload files are detected as "VBA/Agent.DDON!tr", "JS/Agent.DDON!tr.dldr" and "PowerShell/Agent.e535!tr" and are blocked by the FortiGuard Antivirus service.

sentences.text: FortiEDR detects both the Excel file and the huge Powershell file as malicious based on its behavior.
sentences.html: FortiEDR detects both the Excel file and the huge Powershell file as malicious based on its behavior.

sentences.text: In addition to these protections, we suggest that organizations have their end users also go through the FREE NSE training: NSE 1 Information Security Awareness. It includes a module on Internet threats that is designed to help end users learn how to identify and protect themselves from phishing attacks.

It includes a module on Internet threats that is designed to help end users learn how to identify and protect themselves from phishing attacks.
